newsitem.title: USA: Year-end pitfalls await fund investors.
newsitem.headline: Year-end pitfalls await fund investors.

text.p: The average stock fund has climbed nearly 19.8 percent since the end of 1995 -- and the year isn't over yet. Typically, the funds that record the biggest gains during a good year for stocks also draw the most new investors, and this year should be no different.

Trouble is, many of those investors are stepping squarely into a tax trap that could cost them sizable sums. If you invest in a fund that delivered big gains earlier this year, you might have to pay taxes on those gains -- even though you didn't share in the fund's profits.

Here's what you need to know to avoid that trap. In late December, many equity and income funds will make year-end distributions of capital gains earned during the past year. Some funds also will make year-end income distributions.

Now, assume you invest in a fund trading at $21 a share just before it makes its yearly capital gains distribution. Assume that the distribution equals $1. When the distribution is made, the share price will decline from $21 to $20, and you will receive a $1 payment for each share you own. Your total holdings -- the fund shares ($20) and the distribution cash ($1) -- still equal the original $21.
But here's the rub: You now owe taxes on the $1 distribution -- even though the distribution represents part of your original $21 investment.

Believe it or not, some brokers will even try to get you to buy a fund just before a distribution by arguing that you will get a quick dividend to boost your returns. But the only thing you'll boost will be your tax bill.

Before you invest in a fund's shares, call the sponsor and find out when it plans to make a capital gains or income distribution. Then ask them to give you an estimate of how large the distribution will likely be. Finally, ask for the "date of record" for the distribution. You can buy shares after that date without worrying that you'll owe taxes on the distribution.

That phone call could save you a lot of money, especially if you're checking out a fund that has performed very well during the past year. But even a fund that has delivered average gains can be a tax trap for investors. For example, T. Rowe Price Science & Technology Fund (800-638-5660; $2,500 minimum investment; no load) has gained 18 percent so far this year. It will make a projected payout of $3.50 per share on Dec. 27. Assuming the share price remains stable around $34, an investor who puts $5,000 to work in the fund on Dec. 24, 1996 -- just before its distribution date -- will receive a distribution of about $514. If he or she is in the 40 percent combined federal and state tax bracket, that could amount to a $205 tax bill next year.

Some funds will make smaller distributions, of course, and they are not likely to saddle you with such a large tax bill. But who wants to pay taxes -- no matter how small the amount -- on another investor's profits?
(EDITORS: Clint Willis is a freelance writer who covers financial issues for Reuters. Any opinions in the column are solely those of Mr. Willis.)
